newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta call money eases to 10.00/10.25 percent.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta call money eases to 10.00/10.25 percent.

text.p: Jakarta call money eased to 10.00/10.25 percent on Tuesday from 14.0 percent on the back of ample liquidity, dealers said.
One Japanese bank dealer said liquidity was ample following an early supply of 718 billion rupiah into the market.
"I think the amount is more than enough for an early month. Longer-term rates are also seen easing," the dealer said.
One-week money was offered at 11.0/11.5 percent and three-month money at 13.5/14.0 percent.
Dealers said the market could now focus on preparing for the new reserve requirement rate after being haunted by liquidity fears at the end of the 1996/97 fiscal year.
Banks have to meet the new reserve rate of five percent starting April 16.
The average overnight interbank rate on Thursday was 16.28 percent, compared with 16.40 percent on Wednesday.
Bond dealers said the market was slow after a four-day break, with some interest seen on Astra International II bonds.
One said buying interest helped boost Astra bonds' price by 25 basis points, but other prices were stable.
The yield of the benchmark PLN V/A bond remained at 14.625 percent at the last done price of 107.50 percent.
